div.p: The sacramental colloquium has long been concluded; it lasted for about 10 days.

The proceedings were in German, so that the princes and nobles could better understand them. On the other side was Jakob Andreae; Brenz did not open his mouth, but used the other as a kind of legal representative, himself suggesting the plans and arguments. He indeed acted boldly and confidently, but I do not know how well and how piously; let those who will someday read the acts judge about it. Our Boquinus initially began to act in Latin; but because of the princes, the language was changed.

Our Olevianus succeeded for two days, then Ursinus, a distinguished theologian among us, learned and pious, a disciple of Philipp, who concluded the colloquium with such gravity, authority, piety, and modesty, that even the adversaries were astonished and did not obscurely indicate that they feared this bear.
He is the one who composed that book on the supper, which I gave to you. There were two main topics of the dispute: the supper and ubiquity.
The adversaries preferred to first discuss that plausible majesty of the body of Christ; ours did not refuse.

But they were so received and harassed by ours in this majestic field of theirs, that they did not want/want? to descend to the other on the supper. But since only one day was spent disputing the supper, they broke off the colloquium. I hope they do not have much occasion to boast; hence I think there is such silence from yours.
May God grant them a better mind.
